Suchergebnisse sind verfügbar. Verwenden: Search results are avaiable. Use the tab key to navigate.
Sie können auch den Link aus der Adressz: You can also copy the link from the browser's address bar.
Frohe Weihnachten und ein gutes neues Ja: Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year!
ch.sbb.kfk-desc:
The timetable change on 13 December 2015 is the most challenging since the launch of "Rail 2000" in 2004. The map shows the most important changes to SBB long-distance and regional services and building sites which affect the timetable.

Responsible: SBB Passenger Communications, pkom@sbb.ch.
ch.sbb.bahnhofplaene-desc: This layer shows at a glance which stations have an interactive plan application or a station plan in the form of a print product. Rail replacement service plans can also be displayed.
ch.sbb.bahnhofplaene.printprodukte-desc: These stations have a station plan. A poster (A0 or A1 format) and a version which is optimised for printing (A4 format) are always available.
ch.sbb.bahnhofplaene.interaktiv-desc: The layer shows which stations already have interactive plan applications. New stations are constantly being provided with these. The plans are optimised for mobile devices.
ch.sbb.bahnhoffrequenzen-desc:
The number of people who use the railway is displayed for stations and stops of SBB, SOB, Thurbo and Zentralbahn. The figures refer to normal service on working days (Mon–Fri) and include passengers who get on and off trains operated by the following transport companies: SBB, RegionAlps, Thurbo, Zentralbahn, Appenzeller Bahnen, BLS, MGB, MOB, OeBB (Oensingen-Balsthal-Bahn), RhB, SOB, SZU and Travys. Users of other transport companies and other means of public transport and passers-by are not taken into account.
The information refers to 2016.

Data: stat@sbb.ch.
ch.sbb.netzkarte.buslinien-desc: The exact geographic course of the bus routes was established via an automated routing procedure (details). The data are not editorial revised and improved continuously.
ch.sbb.netzkarte-desc:
The network map is aimed at public transport users. It is a basic map derived from timetable data. Relevant information can be accessed directly from the map by clicking on the required station. Under Layer, there is further content which can be displayed on the map.

Responsible: Trafimage System Manager Daniel Hofstetter, trafimage@sbb.ch.
ch.sbb.stationen-desc: The location and attributes of stations are available from a range of data sources. This layer shows the differences between the data sources for all stations in Switzerland. The stations are classified based on their station number (IBNR).
ch.sbb.tracker-desc:
The train tracker shows current connections based on the planned timetable for Swiss public transport.

Data: fahrplanfelder.ch.
ch.sbb.netzkarte.tarifverbunde-desc: Switzerland’s network landscape. Find the right travelcard for you for commuting or leisure from your region’s fare network.
ch.sbb.ch_gemeinden-desc:
Show/hide the municipal borders. You can find municipalities using the search field.

Data:
Federal Statistical Office, swisstopo (01.01.2018)
ch.sbb.parks-desc:
All Swiss parks of national importance at a glance. Only parks which are currently in use are shown.

Data: www.parks.swiss/en.
ch.sbb.dfanachfuehrung-desc: Geographische Darstellung der aktuellen Lage zum Stand der DfA-Nachführung bzgl. Status über Arbeitsfortschritt, Inbe­triebnahme und Abschluss sowie den Stand der periodischen Kontrolle.
ch.sbb.lar-desc:
TINA - Topographical information system network and services:
General overview of the services and infrastructure network via the various outlooks. Representation of the planning data (number of trains, rolling stock, changes between outlooks) and of the key projects as topographical/schematic maps and synopses.
ch.sbb.construction-desc:
This map shows you a selection of SBB’s rail upgrades and maintenance projects – some that are still in the planning stages and others that are currently being implemented. Each entry contains links to websites or fact sheets with the most important project information.

Responsibility lies with: Communications at SBB Infrastructure, Kommunikation-Infrastruktur@sbb.ch
ch.sbb.regionenkarte.public: Coordinators for construction work near railways
ch.sbb.regionenkarte.public-desc:
Find your local contacts for guaranteeing occupational safety on third-party construction sites in the hazardous area of railway infrastructure. The coordinators for construction work near railway installations will help you implement your projects correctly.

Responsible: I-AT-UEW, Aurelia Kollros, aurelia.kollros@sbb.ch
ch.sbb.behig-desc:
To implement the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA), extensive infrastructure adjustments are necessary. This map shows the current status of the SBB stations.

Responsible:
I-AT-KUF-PAM, Simone Mundwiler, simone.mundwiler@sbb.ch
ch.sbb.tarifverbundkarte.public-desc:
Switzerland’s network landscape. Find the right travelcard for you for commuting or leisure from your region’s fare network.

Responsible: SBB Passenger Traffic – Marketing – Conception regional/international
ch.sbb.zweitausbildung-desc:
The detailed geographical map is used to train SBB train crew, counter staff and colleagues in the SBB Contact Center in Brig. With the help of the map, the trainees learn to match specified places, main lines and tourist destinations and routes to their geographical location.

Responsible:

HR-BIL-SKK-PM (VM und VS), pm.skk@sbb.ch
ch.sbb.infrastruktur-desc:
The infrastructure map shows all Swiss railway infrastructure including route operating points. The map differentiates between SBB infrastructure, including subsidiaries, and the infrastructure of other railway companies. The map is primarily used as a background map for SBB internal map topics.

Data status: 2017

Base map status 2017

Contact person: Trafimage System Manager Daniel Hofstetter, trafimage@sbb.ch
Metainformationen: Information about accessible services: This application shows the Swiss public transport network on a map. Different topics (e.g. construction projects) can be selected and levels (e.g. passenger footfall, bus lines and fare networks) can be displayed or hidden. The information is placed on the basic map. Unfortunately, the map application is not yet fully accessible for users with disabilities. Timetable and price information is fully accessible at sbb.ch/en/timetable and on SBB Mobile. You can obtain all other information relating to your mobility by calling the SBB Call Center Handicap on 0800 007 102 free of charge.
ch.sbb.stationen.haltestellen_oev-desc:
Public transport stops (Federal Office of Transport)

The basic geo-data set for public transport stops comprises public transport stops in Switzerland and additional selected geo-referenced public transport locations that are of operational or structural importance (operating points).
ch.sbb.stationen.homog.haltestellen_oev-:
The Federal Office of Transport maintains Switzerland's official stop index together with SBB and in coordination with the cantons and transport companies. Until now, the stops have been shown in the DIDOK list, but now the data is available over the GeoIG dataset public transport stops.
Data source: 2018.
ch.sbb.stationen.homog.didok-desc:
The Federal Office of Transport maintains Switzerland's official stop index together with SBB and in coordination with the cantons and transport companies. Until now, the stops have been shown in the DIDOK list, but now the data is available over the GeoIG dataset public transport stops.
Data source: 2018.
ch.sbb.stationen.homog.dfa-desc:
All operating points are recorded in SBB's database of fixed installations (DfA). In addition to the stations, this also includes other points such as junctions.
Data source: 2017.
ch.sbb.stationen.homog.osm-desc:
In OpenStreetMap, the free world map, stops and often even platform edges are shown with their names and official numbers.
Data source: 2018.
ch.sbb.stationen.homog.hafas-desc:
Stops are also listed in the timetable with their name, their department number and their location. The data is available at fahrplanfelder.ch and gtfs.geops.ch.
Data source: 2018.
